questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for eliciting the corneal reflex during the corneal wisp test? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trigeminal nerve

 

Explanation:


The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex) is a protective mechanism that causes involuntary blinking when the cornea is touched. This reflex involves both sensory and motor components. During a corneal wisp test, a cotton wisp or similar object is brought in from the side (to avoid eliciting a visual reflex) and gently touches the cornea.

 

The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) serves as the afferent (sensory) pathway for this reflex. Specifically, the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve carries the sensory information from the cornea when it is stimulated. The sensory information is then processed, and an efferent (motor) response is generated via the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, resulting in the blink.

 

The corneal sensitivity can be tested more precisely using an instrument called an aesthesiometer, which measures the minimal stimulus required to elicit the blink reflex. Corneal sensation is characteristically decreased in viral corneal ulcers, making this test diagnostically valuable.



 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve: Incorrect. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) is responsible for most eye movements by controlling four of the six extraocular muscles (superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique). It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle (responsible for eyelid elevation) and carries parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction and lens accommodation. It has no role in corneal sensation or the blink reflex pathway.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve: Incorrect. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction of the eye (moving the eye outward, away from the nose). It has no sensory function and does not participate in the corneal reflex pathway.

 

Option D. Facial nerve: Incorrect, but partially involved in the reflex arc. While the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is involved in the corneal reflex, it serves as the efferent (motor) pathway, not the afferent pathway. The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which causes the eyelid to close during blinking. The question specifically asks about the nerve responsible for "eliciting" the reflex, which refers to the sensory component (trigeminal nerve), not the motor response.

 

Educational Objective: 


The corneal reflex is mediated by the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) as the afferent (sensory) pathway and the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) as the efferent (motor) pathway.

choices.text: Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Mechanism of botulinum toxin: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal

 

Explanation: 

 

Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting acetylcholine release from presynaptic terminals. It specifically acts by:

 

  • Inhibiting Synaptobrevin, which is part of the SNARE protein complex
  • SNARE proteins are essential for neurotransmitter exocytosis
  • This inhibition prevents acetylcholine release into the synaptic cleft
  • Results in flaccid paralysis due to lack of neurotransmitter release
  • Clinically used in treating conditions like achalasia cardia, spasms, and contractures

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Inhibit Acetylcholine reuptake: Incorrect because botulinum toxin doesn't affect reuptake mechanisms. It acts specifically on the release mechanism.

 

Option C. Block post synaptic Acetylcholine receptor: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of action for myasthenia gravis where antibodies target post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors. Botulinum toxin acts presynaptically.

 

Option D. Inhibit Acetylcholine esterase: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of action of drugs like neostigmine and pyridostigmine used in treating myasthenia gravis. They prevent the breakdown of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin functions by inhibiting acetylcholine release through its action on SNARE proteins (specifically synaptobrevin) at the presynaptic terminal.

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperopia

 

Esotropia (convergent squint) is commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia).

 

Accommodative esotropia:

 

It occurs due to overaction of convergence associated with accommodation reflex. It is of three types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia (Short-sightedness):

  • Esotropia: Less common in myopic children.
  • Refractive Error: Light focuses in front of the retina.
  • Symptoms: Difficulty seeing distant objects clearly.

 

Option B. Astigmatism:

  • Effect on Squint: Can cause both esotropia and exotropia depending on the axis and severity of astigmatism.
  • Refractive Error: Light is focused at multiple points due to an irregular corneal shape.
  • Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Option D. Emmetropia (Normal Vision):

  • Esotropia: Rarely associated.
  • Refractive Error: No significant refractive error; light focuses correctly on the retina.
  • Symptoms: Normal vision without the need for corrective lenses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperopia is commonly associated with accommodative esotropia in children, where the effort to focus on near objects results in excessive convergence and inward deviation of the eyes. Corrective lenses help to reduce the accommodative effort, thereby alleviating the esotropia.

questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3 deficiency

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia is suggestive of niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Vitamin B3 (also called niacin, nicotinic acid)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1/Thiamine deficiency: can manifest as wet beriberi (CVS features like heart failure and edema), dry beriberi (peripheral neuritis), or as Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis (in alcoholics). Dietary deficiency of thiamine inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6/Pyridoxine deficiency: causes Convulsions, hyperirritability, peripheral neuropathy (deficiency inducible by isoniazid and oral contraceptives), sideroblastic anemia (due to impaired hemoglobin synthesis and iron excess)

 

Option D. Vitamin B12/Cobalamin deficiency: causes Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia, paraesthesia and subacute combined degeneration due to abnormal myelin. Associated with

↑ serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, along with 2° folate deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid abscess

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a parotid abscess.
  • It is suppuration of the parotid space. Deep cervical fascia splits into two layers, superficial and deep, to enclose the parotid gland and its associated structures. Parotid space lies deep to its superficial layer.
  • Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases and debilitated patients, with stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause.
  • Most common organism- Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Presents with unilateral swelling associated with redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present.
  • Investigations -
    • Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan – to know extent of abscess
    • Aspiration of abscess for culture and sensitivity to isolate causative organism
  • Treatment -
    • Surgical drainage of the abscess is done via a preauricular incision along with IV antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: is a complication of mastoiditis which presents as swelling in upper part of neck when pus breaks inferiorly, through the tip of the mastoid

 

Option C. Upper cervical lymphadenopathy: occurs in the neck region following infection in the area drained by these structures.

 

Option D. Osteoma of the mandible: characterized by a benign, slow-growing tumor on the mandible, which is usually painless and asymptomatic, not presenting with tenderness and acute symptoms like an abscess.

 

Educational Objective:


Diagnosing and treating a parotid abscess promptly is crucial to prevent further complications such as the spread of infection. The characteristic presentation of swelling, tenderness, and systemic signs in a specific location aids in differential diagnosis from other potential conditions affecting the neck and jaw area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 297

questions.text: A 22y type 1 DM is in the post operative ward following a cesarean done for failed induction (for preeclampsia with severe features). She complains of drowsiness and altered sensorium. She is on maintenance MgSO4 infusion and on IV infusion of insulin. On examination, her PR is 70/ min. BP is 140/ 98 mmHg. RR is 10/min. Auscultation of lungs reveals bilateral normal air entry. Abdominal examination reveals a firm uterus with normal tenderness. Pfannenstiel scar is intact and there is no significant vaginal bleeding. B/l patellar reflexes are absent. A urine dipstick for protein and sugar is negative and a capillary glucose sample is 270 mg%. The suspected diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnesium sulphate toxicity

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity.
  • MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia.
  • The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L
  • When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:
  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
  • Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis: This is unlikely as urine for sugars is absent.

 

Option C. Postpartum eclampsia: This is unlikely as there is no history of seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: There is no evidence of cardiac failure and hence this is also unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia, it is critical to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity, which include loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest. The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate.

 

Ref: Page no 1860, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: Give antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation
Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation
Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a cough with yellowish sputum. Auscultation revealed bronchial breath sounds. He is hemodynamically stable and not confused. On examination, his respiratory rate is 20/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Lab reports show urea levels of 44 mg/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

 

The patient's presentation suggests a lower respiratory tract infection, likely pneumonia, given the cough with yellow sputum and bronchial breath sounds on auscultation. The management decision can be guided by the CURB-65 score, which helps determine the severity of pneumonia and the need for hospitalization.

 

The CURB-65 score components are:

 

  • Confusion: No
  • Urea > 7 mmol/L (19 mg/dL): Yes (urea is 44 mg/dL)
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min: No (respiratory rate is 20/min)
  • Blood pressure (systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg): No (BP is 110/70 mmHg)
  • Age ≥ 65 years: Yes (patient is 68 years old)

 

The patient has two points (urea > 19 mg/dL and age ≥ 65 years).

 

Based on the CURB-65 score:

 

  • 0 points: Outpatient treatment
  • 1 point: Consider outpatient treatment or short inpatient stay
  • 2 points: Inpatient treatment
  • 3-5 points: Consider ICU admission

 

The patient scores 2 points, indicating the need for inpatient treatment but not necessarily in the ICU.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give antibiotics and send the patient home: This would be appropriate for a patient with a CURB-65 score of 0 or possibly 1, but not for a score of 2, which indicates a higher risk that necessitates closer monitoring in an inpatient setting.

 

Option B. Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation: ICU admission is generally reserved for patients with a CURB-65 score of 3 or higher, indicating severe pneumonia. This patient's condition does not meet those criteria.

 

Option C. Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation: This is appropriate for patients with very severe pneumonia (CURB-65 score of 4-5) or those in respiratory distress, neither of which applies to this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with pneumonia, the CURB-65 score is a useful tool for determining the appropriate level of care. A score of 2 typically indicates the need for inpatient treatment in a non-ICU setting.

questions.text: Paris green powder is used for killing of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anopheles larva

 

Paris green powder is a chemical compound known as copper acetoarsenate, which is used as an anti-larval agent in the control of mosquito populations, under National Vector Borne Disease Control Program, India.

 

The mechanism of action of Paris green is that it acts as a stomach poison when ingested by the larvae. This disrupts the normal biological functions of the larvae, effectively killing them before they can mature into adult mosquitoes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria parasite: Paris green powder does not target the malaria parasite directly. Instead, it targets the mosquito larvae, which are vectors for the parasite.

 

Option C. Mites: Paris green powder is not effective against mites; it is specifically used against mosquito larvae.

 

Option D. Adult mosquito: While there are chemical agents such as DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion that are used to target adult mosquitoes. These adulticides work as nerve or contact poisons, inhibiting the acetylcholinesterase enzyme in adult mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antilarval measures: Paris green – 2% dust applied in dose of 1 kg per hectare; ‘stomach poison’ to larvae but harmless to humans, animals or fish

 

Antiadult measures: DDT, pyrethrum, and malathion

choices.text: Pre- invasive diagnostic test

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue pregnancy

 

Explanation

 

  • The risks for malformations, growth restriction, or abortion are not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).
  • Since diagnostic X-rays seldom exceed 0.1 Gy (10 rads), the risk is negligible. A 0.1 Gy exposure is equivalent to more than 1000 chest X-rays.
  • Hence, continuing pregnancy is the most appropriate advice to this woman.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Terminate pregnancy: Termination is not necessary as the radiation dose from a single chest X-ray is significantly lower than the threshold for increased risks.

 

Option C. Pre-invasive diagnostic test: This is not required in this scenario as the radiation dose is too low to justify invasive diagnostics.

 

Option D. Chromosome screening: Chromosome screening is unnecessary because the radiation dose from a chest X-ray does not significantly increase the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective

 

The risk for fetal malformations, growth restriction, or abortion is not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).

 

Ref: Page 2265, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Vector for Scrub typhus / Orientia tsutsugamushi is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mite

 

Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. The primary vector for this disease is not the adult mite but its larval form, known as a chigger. Chiggers are tiny, red larval mites that transmit the bacteria to humans through their bite. The disease is also sometimes referred to as "chigger-borne rickettsiosis" due to this vector relationship.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tick: While ticks are vectors for other rickettsial diseases such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever (caused by Rickettsia rickettsii) and Indian tick typhus (caused by Rickettsia conorii), they are not responsible for transmitting scrub typhus.

 

 

Option B. Louse: Lice are vectors for epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. They do not transmit scrub typhus.

 

 

Option C. Flea: Fleas are vectors for endemic typhus caused by Rickettsia typhi. They are not associated with scrub typhus transmission.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickettsial diseases:

questions.text: A long-standing smoker has shortness of breath, and spirometry shows FEV₁ 60% with FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.6. Which of the following is the likely cause of the findings in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) COPD

 

The spirometry findings are classic for an obstructive lung disorder. An FEV₁ less than 80% and an FEV₁/FVC ratio less than 0.7 are diagnostic criteria for obstructive lung disease. The patient's long-standing smoking history and these specific spirometry results strongly point to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), which includes conditions like chronic bronchitis and emphysema.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Silicosis: This is a restrictive lung disorder caused by inhalation of silica dust, typically seen in workers like miners and sandblasters. It would show a reduced FEV₁/FVC ratio characteristic of restrictive lung diseases, not obstructive.

 

Option B. Interstitial lung disease: Another restrictive lung disorder characterized by inflammation and scarring of lung tissue. It would also demonstrate reduced lung volumes and a decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio typical of restrictive diseases.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic carcinoma: While associated with smoking, this is a space-occupying lesion that might affect lung function but is not primarily a cause of obstructive lung disease. It would not typically cause the classic spirometry changes seen in this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.7 indicates obstructive lung disease. COPD is the most common obstructive lung disease in smokers, while conditions like silicosis and interstitial lung disease present with restrictive patterns (normal or increased FEV₁/FVC ratio).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with multiple patches of hair loss which was associated with itching and scaling. His 2-year-old sister also had similar complaints. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tinea capitis

 

Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that commonly affects children. It is characterized by multiple patches of hair loss, which are often associated with itching and scaling.

 

The history of a sibling with similar symptoms strongly suggests an infectious cause, which aligns with the diagnosis of tinea capitis. The condition is caused by dermatophyte fungi, and the transmission occurs via direct contact or shared objects, making it contagious, particularly among children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alopecia areata: This condition leads to sudden, patchy hair loss but is not associated with itching, scaling, or being contagious. It is an autoimmune disorder rather than an infection, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this context.

 

Option C. Seborrheic dermatitis: While this condition can cause scalp scaling, it typically does not lead to well-defined patches of hair loss or the contagious spread noted in this case.

 

Option D. Pediculosis capitis: Also known as head lice, this condition causes intense itching but does not result in patchy hair loss or scaling. The primary symptom is the presence of lice and nits (lice eggs) on the scalp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea capitis is a contagious fungal infection that presents with patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling, particularly in children, and can spread among family members.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

 

Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid (Soft Chancre), a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy, not urethritis. Urethritis involves inflammation of the urethra, typically presenting with symptoms such as dysuria and discharge. H. ducreyi specifically causes ulcerative lesions rather than the typical inflammation and discharge associated with urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: While primarily known for causing trichomoniasis (a vaginitis), Trichomonas can occasionally cause urethritis, particularly in women.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly among sexually transmitted bacterial infections.

 

Option C. Gonococcus (Neisseria gonorrhoeae): A well-known cause of gonococcal urethritis, presenting typically with a more severe and purulent discharge compared to NGU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of Alzheimer disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amyloid beta plaque

 

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of senile dementia, characterized by the accumulation of amyloid beta plaques in the brain. These plaques are abnormal clumps of protein that disrupt cell function and are a hallmark of Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

The presence of amyloid beta plaques contributes to neurodegeneration, synaptic dysfunction, and cognitive decline observed in Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha synuclein: This protein is associated with Parkinson’s disease and Lewy body dementia, where it forms abnormal aggregates called Lewy bodies. It is not a marker for Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Option C. Glial fibrillary associated protein: This protein is found in astrocytes and is commonly associated with gliosis, not specifically with Alzheimer’s disease. It is not a marker for Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

Option D. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein found in muscle tissue and is related to muscle disorders, not neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloid beta plaque is a key pathological marker of Alzheimer’s disease, contributing significantly to the neurodegenerative changes seen in this condition.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which embryonic pharyngeal arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 6th arch

 

The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.

 

  • During embryonic development, the aortic arches give rise to several structures in the neck and chest.
  • The 6th arch artery, which is present on both the right and left sides, gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus.
  • As the arch arteries regress and are replaced by the adult structures, the recurrent laryngeal nerves, which innervate the muscles of the larynx, become trapped behind the great vessels.
  • The distal 6th arch artery vanishes on the right side. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under the 4th arch artery, which becomes the future right subclavian artery, because there is no 5th arch artery.
  • On the left side, the 6th arch artery persists, which develops into ductus arteriosus, which later forms ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under it and therefore, has a relatively long course.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch on its way to the larynx.
  • In the case of the long left recurrent laryngeal nerve, the nerve passes inferior to the ligamentum arteriosum, which is a remnant of the ductus arteriosus that is derived from the 6th arch artery.
  •  This can lead to an increased risk of injury to the nerve during surgical procedures involving the thorax or neck.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 3rd pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries and the proximal part of the internal carotid arteries.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: It is not directly related to the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, its persistence or anomalies don't affect the recurrent laryngeal nerve's course.

 

Option B. 4th arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 4th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the left side into the arch of the aorta and on the right side into the right subclavian artery.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which arises from the vagus nerve, initially descends and then ascends around the 4th arch artery. However, this is not responsible for the long course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. 5th arch:

 

  • Derivative: Interestingly, in many cases, the 5th pharyngeal arch artery is rudimentary or even absent in humans. When present, it doesn't form any significant structures in the mature circulatory system.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: Given its rudimentary nature, the 5th arch artery doesn't have a defined relationship with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.

 

Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked 1 in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fossa of Rosenmuller

 

 

The image represented is the endoscopic view of lateral wall of the nasopharynx. Structure marked 1 is Fossa of Rosenmüller.

1 - FOSSA OF ROSENMULLER

2 - TORUS TUBARIUS

3 - POSTERIOR PHARYNGEAL WALL

4 - EUSTACHIAN TUBE OPENING

Lateral wall of nasopharynx contains Eustachian tube opening in the form of a bulge called torus tubarius and fossa of Rosenmüller lies behind this elevation (most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma)

 

The tubal tonsil is a small lymphoid tissue located at the tubal elevation near the opening of the eustachian tube.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubal Tonsil: Lymphoid tissue near the opening of the Eustachian tube but not visible as marked in this image.

 

Option C. Opening of Eustachian Tube: Located anterior to the Fossa of Rosenmuller, usually at the torus tubarius, not visible in the marked area.

 

Option D. Adenoid: Lymphoid tissue located on the posterior wall of the nasopharynx, not in the lateral wall and thus not visible in this specific view.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fossa of Rosenmuller's familiarity is essential in nasopharyngeal examinations, especially in the context of identifying potential sites for nasopharyngeal carcinoma or other pathologies. Its recognition during endoscopy guides thorough inspection and appropriate clinical interventions.

questions.text: A patient present with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and other related symptoms. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin C

 

The clinical features described are classic signs of Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy)

 

  • Gum bleeding and inflammation
  • Petechiae (due to capillary fragility)
  • Poor wound healing
  • These occur because Vitamin C is essential for: 
  1. Collagen synthesis - hydroxylation of proline and lysine
  2. Maintaining blood vessel integrity
  3. Wound healing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency presents with: 
    • Night blindness (earliest symptom)
    • Bitot's spots (most specific)
    • Xerophthalmia
    • Keratomalacia

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency presents with: 
    • Neurological symptoms
    • Seborrheic dermatitis
    • Glossitis
    • Convulsions in infants

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency leads to Pellagra characterized by 4Ds: 
    • Dermatitis (photosensitive)
    • Diarrhea
    • Dementia
    • Death

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classic triad of scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency): gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and petechiae/easy bruising. Understand that these symptoms occur due to impaired collagen synthesis and compromised blood vessel integrity.

questions.text: Injury to which nerve results in absent gag reflex? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX & X

 

The gag reflex, also known as the pharyngeal reflex, is a protective mechanism that prevents foreign objects from entering the throat. This reflex involves both sensory and motor components:

 

  • Sensory Component (Afferent): The sensory part of the gag reflex is mediated by the Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX). When the posterior wall of the pharynx or the palate is touched, the sensory information is carried by the Glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla oblongata.
  • Motor Component (Efferent): The motor response, which causes the contraction of the pharyngeal muscles, is mediated by the Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X). This nerve provides the efferent pathway, leading to the muscle contraction observed in the gag reflex.

 

Injury to either of these nerves can disrupt the reflex: damage to CN IX affects the sensory input, while damage to CN X affects the motor response, resulting in an absent gag reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (VII & X): Cranial Nerve VII (Facial nerve) is not involved in the gag reflex. The Facial nerve primarily controls muscles of facial expression and does not play a role in the sensory or motor aspects of the gag reflex.

 

Option C (V & IX): Cranial Nerve V (Trigeminal nerve) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing, not for the gag reflex. Therefore, its involvement in the gag reflex is incorrect.

 

Option D (VII & IX): While Cranial Nerve IX is correctly identified as part of the reflex, Cranial Nerve VII is not involved. This makes the pairing incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gag reflex involves the Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for sensory input and the Vagus nerve (CN X) for motor response. Damage to either nerve can result in an absent gag reflex.

questions.text: A patient after RTA (Road Traffic Accident) presented with hypovolemic shock. What is the reason for decreased cardiac output in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased preload

 

Hypovolemic shock, often caused by significant blood loss as in the case of a road traffic accident (RTA), leads to a decrease in the volume of blood returning to the heart (preload). Preload is the initial stretching of the cardiac myocytes prior to contraction, which is directly related to the volume of blood filling the heart. When there is a significant loss of blood volume, the preload decreases, leading to a reduced stroke volume and, consequently, decreased cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased afterload: This refers to the resistance the heart must overcome to eject blood. Increased afterload is not a primary issue in hypovolemic shock.

 

Option C. High systemic vascular resistance: This would be more characteristic of distributive shock, such as septic shock, rather than hypovolemic shock.

 

Option D. Decreased contractility: While decreased contractility can reduce cardiac output, in hypovolemic shock, the primary problem is the loss of blood volume leading to decreased preload, not a primary issue with the heart muscle's ability to contract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hypovolemic shock, the primary cause of decreased cardiac output is decreased preload due to significant loss of blood volume.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

The given scenario and image is most likely to be of Fournier gangrene which is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

 

FOURNIER’S GANGRENE

 

  • Synergistic gangrene of scrotum and perineum
  • Limited to skin and fascial planes - type of necrotising fasciitis
  • Never breaches the tunica, testis always spared
  • Risk factors - Low immunity, uncontrolled diabetes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases: Anti-gas gangrene serum is obsolete now.

 

Option B. Urinary diversion is the next step: Urinary diversion is not the next best step.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy must be done: Testes are preserved during debridement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier gangrene is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET  PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher’s Disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed, which revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions. What will be the next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MR spectroscopy

 

MR spectroscopy is the next best step when multiple ring-enhancing lesions are observed in the basal parts of the brain, suggesting tuberculomas. MR spectroscopy helps differentiate tuberculomas from other similar conditions, like neurocysticercosis (NCC), by identifying a characteristic lipid-lactate peak. The presence of this peak strongly favors a diagnosis of tuberculosis rather than NCC, which typically does not show this peak. This approach is a non-invasive and specific method to further evaluate the lesions, aligning with standard clinical protocols.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CBNAAT of CSF: CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) of CSF is mainly used for confirming tuberculous meningitis rather than localized brain lesions such as tuberculomas. It is not useful in directly evaluating ring-enhancing lesions seen on MRI.

 

Option C. Biopsy: Biopsy is an invasive procedure and is usually not the first choice due to potential complications. It is reserved for cases where non-invasive methods fail to provide a definitive diagnosis.

 

Option D. SWI (Susceptibility-Weighted Imaging): SWI is used primarily for detecting bleeds, microhemorrhages, or diffuse axonal injuries. It does not contribute to the diagnosis of ring-enhancing lesions caused by infections like tuberculosis or neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal brain region on MRI suggests tuberculomas, and MR spectroscopy is the preferred next step to confirm the diagnosis by detecting a lipid-lactate peak.

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of variation

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is used to compare the relative variability of different datasets. It is a standardized measure of dispersion of a probability distribution or frequency distribution. The CV is particularly useful because it expresses the standard deviation as a percentage of the mean, making it possible to compare the degree of variation from one dataset to another, regardless of the unit of measurement or magnitude of the mean.

 

  • Co-efficient of Variation [COV] = SD/Mean x 100
  • It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: Variance measures the spread of a set of numbers. It is the average of the squared differences from the mean. While it indicates variability, it does not provide a standardized measure for comparison between different datasets.

 

Option C. Standard Error of Mean (SEM): The SEM measures how much the sample mean of the data is likely to vary from the true population mean. It is used to understand the accuracy of the sample mean but is not used for comparing variability between datasets.

 

Option D. Standard Deviation (SD): Standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values. While it indicates the spread of data points, it does not standardize this measure in relation to the mean, which is necessary for comparing different datasets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

 

  • Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.
  • The commonly implemented methods for identifying Candida are 10% potassium hydroxide stain and culture with sabouraud dextrose agar. Differentiation of specific species is possible with special culture mediums like CHROMagar Candida. 
  • ELISA and PCR tests are used in cases of invasive candidiasis and to differentiate Candida dubliniensis from Candida albicans.
  • It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.
  • It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

 

Option C. Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

 

Option D. Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudo membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

choices.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics
Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

 

In the given clinical scenario, it is important to establish or rule out a diagnosis of HIV infection before evaluating for secondary infections. Therefore, the next best step is to obtain a dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR. AIDS enteropathy, a syndrome of malabsorption with partial villous atrophy not associated with a specific pathogen, has been postulated to be a result of direct HIV infection of the gut.

 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in infants born to HIV-infected mothers is done using various methods, including HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program now uses an HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample.

 

Infants born to HIV-positive mothers should be exclusively breastfed or fed with replacement feeds exclusively until 6 months of age. Infants should also receive AR prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine.

 

It is common for HIV-infected infants to experience gastrointestinal tract involvement, with bacteria (Salmonella, Campylobacter, Shigella, Mycobacterium avium complex), protozoa (Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Isospora, microsporidia), viruses (CMV, HSV, rotavirus), and fungi (Candida) being common pathogens. MAC and protozoal infections tend to be the most severe and prolonged in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Test stool for giardiasis and give antibiotics: This is not the preferred immediate next step. First, the diagnosis of HIV infection should be established before treating secondary infections.

 

Option C. Antibody tests for HIV: Antibody tests for HIV are not useful in establishing the diagnosis of HIV infection in infants. This is because all infants born to HIV-infected mothers test antibodies positive at birth due to the passive transfer of maternal HIV antibodies across the placenta. It can be used as a diagnostic tool after 18 months of age.

 

Option D. Aerobic culture: Aerobic culture is not used for the diagnosis of HIV infection. It is more relevant for identifying bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse four days back came with complaints of painful urethral discharge. What is the treatment of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg stat

 

The patient's history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the rapid onset of painful urethral discharge are highly indicative of gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Gonococcal urethritis typically presents with dysuria (painful urination) and a purulent (pus-like) discharge from the urethra.

 

The treatment of choice for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. Cefixime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This treatment is preferred due to its efficacy in eradicating the infection and its convenience as a single-dose therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 2 weeks: Doxycycline is typically used for treating chlamydial infections, which can co-occur with gonorrhea but is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea itself. Additionally, a two-week course is usually prescribed for chlamydia, not gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Benzathine Penicillin: Benzathine Penicillin is primarily used for treating syphilis, not gonorrhea. Syphilis and gonorrhea are different sexually transmitted infections with distinct treatments.

 

Option D. Azithromycin 1 gm stat: Azithromycin can be used in the treatment of chlamydial infections, often alongside treatment for gonorrhea to cover potential co-infection. However, it is not the first-line treatment for gonorrhea when given alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for gonococcal urethritis is a single dose of Cefixime 400 mg stat. This treatment is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacteria responsible for the infection.

choices.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.text: Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA helicase

 

Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to a defect in DNA helicase.

 

This rare genetic disorder is characterized by premature aging, with patients typically experiencing symptoms associated with aging at an accelerated rate. The defective gene product in Werner syndrome is a DNA helicase, a protein that plays a key role in DNA replication and repair by unwinding the double helix structure of DNA.

 

 

A defect in this enzyme leads to the rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage, which can mimic the cellular aging process. This chromosomal damage is believed to contribute to the Clinical features of Werner syndrome, such as premature graying and hair loss, thinning and wrinkling of the skin and hyperpigmentation, cataracts, osteoporosis, Short Stature, Metabolic Abnormalities and an increased risk of cancer.

 

The diagnosis of Werner syndrome is typically based on clinical features, family history, and genetic testing. There is no cure for Werner syndrome, and treatment is primarily supportive and focused on managing symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased telomerase activity: Increased telomerase activity typically prevents telomere shortening, which is not associated with the premature aging seen in Werner syndrome.

 

Option C. Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity: Decreased telomerase activity leads to shortened telomeres, not an increase in length. However, telomere lengthening is not a feature of Werner syndrome.

 

Option D. Reduced free radicals: Reduced free radicals would theoretically reduce oxidative damage and potentially slow aging. This is not related to the premature aging observed in Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Premature aging in Werner syndrome is primarily due to a defect in DNA helicase, leading to rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage and the manifestation of aging-related symptoms at an accelerated rate.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida is in labor. She has a repeated urge to pass urine and has premature bearing down. On examination there is infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart is heard on the lateral side. What is the most likely presentation/ position? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occipito-posterior

 

Explanation:

 

Occipito-posterior:

 

  • History:
    • Early rupture of membranes.
    • Frequent filling of bladder.
    • Premature bearing down.
  • Abdominal Examination:
    • Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus.
    • Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions.
    • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly.
  • Vaginal Examination:
    • An elongated bag of membranes.
    • The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint.
    • The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Brow: The brow presentation involves partial extension of the fetal head. The presenting diameter is larger, leading to a more difficult labor. However, this would not typically present with infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option B. Knee: A knee presentation is a form of breech presentation where the knees are the presenting part. It is rare and would not cause infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option D. Right dorso-anterior: This position involves the fetus's back being to the mother's right and anterior. It would not cause infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart sounds like the occipito-posterior position does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occipito-posterior position in labor is characterized by infra-umbilical flattening, frequent filling of the bladder, premature bearing down, and fetal heart sounds heard on the lateral side.

 

 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

 

ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 

Pathology - Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous type. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterative endarteritis. The bone of turbinates undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers. Paranasal sinuses are small due to their arrested development.

 

Clinical Features

 

  1. Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty
  2. Foul smell from the nose though the patient himself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
  3. Patients may complain of nasal obstruction due to large crusts filling the nose.
  4. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

 

On examination shows

 

  1. Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or grayish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  2. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.
  3. Nasal mucosa appears pale. Septal perforation and dermatitis of nasal vestibule may be present. Nose may show a saddle deformity.
  4.  Atrophic changes may also be seen in the pharyngeal mucosa larynx.
  5. Hearing impairment may be noticed because of obstruction to the eustachian tube and middle ear effusion.
  6. Paranasal sinuses are usually small and underdeveloped with thick walls.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

 

Surgical management:

 

  • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyps: These are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: It is associated with various mucosal diseases which include allergic rhinitis, infectious rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: It is commonly seen in children and the child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 172, 173

choices.text: Attend the summon which was received earlier
Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon

questions.text: A forensic doctor is facing criminal charges for malpractice in a district criminal court and is also summoned to provide expert testimony in a district civil court for which he will be provided compensation. What is the correct statement in this scenario? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Attend Criminal Court

 

Explanation:


When receiving summons from multiple courts, the priority is determined by the following factors:

 

  1. Court Rank: Higher courts take precedence over lower courts.
  2. Case Type: Criminal cases are prioritized over civil cases.
    The ranking of the court is more significant than the type of case. For instance, if one summons is from a higher court for a civil case and another is from a lower court for a criminal case, the higher court should be attended.
  3. Timeliness: If both court rank and case type are the same, the court whose summons was received first should be attended.

 

In this case:

 

  • Both courts are of same rank (district court)
  • One case is criminal and other is civil
  • Criminal cases take precedence over civil cases even if compensation is offered

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Attend Civil Court: Incorrect. Even though compensation is offered, civil court attendance does not take precedence over criminal court when summons are received simultaneously.

 

Option C. Attend the summon which was received earlier: Incorrect. While timing of summons receipt is a criterion, it only applies when both courts are of same rank and type. Criminal cases take precedence regardless of when summons was received.

 

Option D. Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon: Incorrect. Ignoring court summons and waiting for second summons is not appropriate. One must attend according to the priority.

 

Educational Objective:


Order of Court Ranking (Highest to Lowest):

 

  1. Supreme Court & High Court
  2. Sessions Court / District Court / Additional Sessions Judge / Additional District Judge
  3. Assistant Sessions Judge
  4. Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM) / Chief Metropolitan Magistrate (CMM)
  5. 1st Class Judicial Magistrate (JM) / Metropolitan Magistrate (MM)
  6. 2nd Class Judicial Magistrate (JM)

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening of immigrants to a country

 

Prospective screening is conducted primarily for the benefit of the community or the public health system, rather than for the direct benefit of the individual being screened. It aims to control the spread of diseases and protect public health by identifying potential carriers of infectious diseases or individuals with certain health conditions that may pose a risk to others.

 

Screening of immigrants to a country: This is a classic example of prospective screening. It is done to detect infectious diseases or other health conditions in immigrants to prevent the spread of disease and protect the health of the population in the host country. This screening is often mandated by public health authorities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient:  This is an example of prescriptive screening, as it is conducted for the individual's benefit to detect cervical cancer early.

 

Option B. Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism:  This is also an example of prescriptive screening aimed at early detection and management of hypothyroidism in newborns.

 

Option D. Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man:  This is another example of prescriptive screening, used to detect diabetes in the individual.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child came with malnutrition and follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions. There was a deficiency of Vitamin A and Essential Fatty Acids. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as "toad skin," is a type of dermatosis characterized by hyperkeratotic papules that primarily occur over the extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. This condition is closely associated with nutritional deficiencies, particularly of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids. In severe cases, deficiencies in other vitamins like Vitamin B complex, Vitamin C, and Vitamin E have also been observed to contribute to this condition.

 

The presentation of follicular hyperkeratotic lesions in a malnourished child, along with documented deficiencies of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, strongly points to phrynoderma. Recognizing this characteristic presentation is crucial in diagnosing and treating the condition effectively.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin C and is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, bruising, and petechiae, but it does not typically cause follicular hyperkeratotic lesions. Therefore, this is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Option C. Keratosis pilaris: This is a common, benign condition that presents with rough, small, acne-like bumps, typically on the arms, thighs, cheeks, and buttocks. It is not associated with the nutritional deficiencies described in the question, making it an unlikely diagnosis here.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis (Darier's disease): This is a genetic skin disorder characterized by greasy, warty papules and plaques in seborrheic areas like the scalp, forehead, upper arms, chest, and back. It is not associated with vitamin deficiencies or malnutrition, which makes it an in Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is associated with malnutrition and deficiencies in Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, and it presents with follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions, particularly over the elbows and knees.

choices.text: Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is NOT used as a first line therapy for ADHD? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors

 

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is commonly treated with stimulant medications, which are the first line of treatment. The main drugs of choice include methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, and dextroamphetamine. These medications work by increasing dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain, improving concentration and reducing impulsivity and hyperactivity.

 

Atomoxetine, although not a stimulant, is also used as a treatment option for ADHD. It works as a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and is considered a non-stimulant alternative, especially useful in patients who may not respond well to stimulants or who have contraindications.

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), such as venlafaxine and duloxetine, are primarily used as antidepressants and are not typically used as first-line or preferred treatments for ADHD. These medications target different neurotransmitter systems and do not specifically address the core symptoms of ADHD as effectively as stimulants or atomoxetine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylphenidate: alpha agonist: This is incorrect because methylphenidate is a stimulant and a common first-line treatment for ADHD, although it is not an alpha agonist. It increases dopamine and norepinephrine activity in the brain.

 

Option B. Dexmethylphenidate or Dextroamphetamine: Dexmethylphenidate is a derivative of methylphenidate and is also a drug of choice for ADHD, working similarly to increase dopamine and norepinephrine levels.

 

Dextroamphetamine is a stimulant that is often used in the management of ADHD due to its efficacy in increasing dopamine and norepinephrine release, which helps in reducing ADHD symptoms.

 

Option C. Atomoxetine: antidepressant: Although it is referred to as an antidepressant, atomoxetine is actually a non-stimulant specifically approved for the treatment of ADHD, making it a valid option for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are not the drugs of choice for ADHD, whereas stimulants like methylphenidate and dextroamphetamine, and non-stimulants like atomoxetine, are preferred treatments.

 

Remember -

 

  • Drugs used:
  • Methylphenidate: alpha agonist
  • Dx methylphenidate
  • Dextro amphetamine
  • Atomoxetine: antidepressant
  • Tricyclic antidepressants like
  • Imipramine
  • Clonidine, guanfacine

questions.text: What is the compression to ventilation ratio in an adult cardiac arrest patient in the presence of more than one rescuer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30:2

 

In adult patients experiencing cardiac arrest, the recommended compression to ventilation ratio during CPR is 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers present. This ratio ensures that adequate chest compressions are delivered to maintain blood circulation while allowing time for sufficient ventilation to oxygenate the blood. The priority in adult CPR is effective chest compressions, which is why the ratio is set to 30 compressions for every 2 ventilations.

 

This ratio remains constant irrespective of whether there is one rescuer or more than one, ensuring consistency and simplicity during the resuscitation process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For adult CPR, regardless of the number of rescuers, the compression to ventilation ratio should always be 30:2 to ensure effective circulation and oxygenation during cardiac arrest.

 

Additionally, For children with one rescuer, the ratio is 30 compressions to 2 ventilations (30:2); with two rescuers, the ratio is 15 compressions to 2 ventilations (15:2). For neonates, the ratio is 3 compressions to 1 ventilation (3:1).

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lateral medullary syndrome

 

The patient's presentation with loss of pain and temperature sensation from the left side of the face and the right side of the body, along with dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex, suggests involvement of the lateral medulla. Additionally, the presence of Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) on the left side further supports this diagnosis.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). The key clinical features include:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face due to involvement of the spinal trigeminal nucleus.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysarthria and dysphagia due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (cranial nerves IX and X).
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome due to disruption of the descending sympathetic pathways.
  • Ataxia due to involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral pontine syndrome: Lateral pontine syndrome involves the pons and typically affects cranial nerves that are not involved in this patient's presentation. For example, it often involves the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), leading to facial weakness, which is not described in this case.

 

Option B. Medial medullary syndrome: Medial medullary syndrome affects the medial structures of the medulla, including the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), and results in ipsilateral tongue weakness and contralateral hemiparesis. This does not match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Locked-In Syndrome: Locked-In Syndrome results from bilateral lesions in the ventral pons, leading to quadriplegia and anarthria, but with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements. The patient's symptoms do not align with this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is characterized by ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague. This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.


 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:

 

 

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.

 

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.

 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Species Phlebotomus argentipes: belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C. Ixodes Tick: transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quinsy

 

The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

 

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever.

 

EXAMINATION FINDINGS

 

  1. The tonsil, pillars and soft palate on the involved side are congested and swollen. Tonsil itself may not appear enlarged as it gets buried in the oedematous pillars
  2. Uvula is swollen and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side.
  3. Bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil.
  4. Mucopus may be seen covering the tonsillar region.
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy is commonly seen. This involves jugulodigastric lymph nodes.
  6. Torticollis. Patient keeps the neck tilted to the side of abscess

 

Investigations - Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI shows the abscess and its extent. Needle aspiration of an abscess provides material for culture and sensitivity of bacteria.

 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngitis: Typically presents with a sore throat and possible fever but lacks the severe localized symptoms and findings of quinsy.

 

Option B. Parotid abscess: Would likely present with swelling and pain in the parotid gland area, externally visible.

 

Option C. Bezold's Abscess: An infection that spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, which would involve more distinct signs of ear and mastoid involvement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with spotting PV following insertion of an IUD. What is the best management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron supplementation

 

This is the recommendation by the ministry of health and family welfare. Usually spotting settles done in a few months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remove the IUD: Removal of the IUD is not indicated for mild spotting. It is a normal response and should be managed conservatively.

 

Option C. Oral antibiotics: Antibiotics are not required unless there is evidence of an infection, which is not indicated by mere spotting.

 

Option D. Reassurance and observe: Spotting following the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD) is a common and expected side effect. It typically occurs due to the body's inflammatory response to the new device in the uterus, which can cause mild cramping and spotting. The best management in this situation is to reassure the patient and observe the symptoms. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be given to alleviate cramps and reduce spotting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron supplementation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoea

 

The history of multiple sexual partners and lower abdominal pain with discharge and intermenstrual bleed suggests a diagnosis of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, of which cause can be N. Gonorrhoea among the given options.

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

 

 

Treatment –

 

KIT 6 (Yellow) – Tab Cefixime 400mg 1 Tab

 

  • Tab Metronidazole 400 mg (1 tab BD x 1 days)
  •  Tab Doxycycline 100 mg (1 tab BD x 21 days)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex causes painful genital ulcers.

 

Option B. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis is seen in sexually inactive females

 

Option C. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents as intense pruritus and white discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections, with Neisseria gonorrhoeae being a major pathogen, especially in women with multiple sexual partners presenting with lower abdominal pain and intermenstrual bleeding.

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) B (Rice)

 

Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. The primary dietary sources of thiamine are whole cereal grains, meat, and fish. In the context of the image provided, the food item labeled "B" corresponds to rice, which is a significant source of thiamine.

 

Rice, particularly unpolished or whole rice, contains a high level of thiamine in its outer layer. However, polished rice, commonly consumed in many parts of the world, loses much of its thiamine content due to the removal of the outer layer during polishing. This loss is a contributing factor to thiamine deficiency in populations that primarily consume polished rice, leading to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, especially among chronic alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Cucumber and onion: These items are not significant sources of thiamine. Vegetables like cucumbers and onions contain very low levels of thiamine and are not considered a primary dietary source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Chapati/Flatbread: Chapatis are made from wheat flour, which does contain some thiamine. However, it is not as significant a source as rice, particularly in the whole grain form.

 

Option D. Dal/Lentil Curry: While lentils do contain some thiamine, they are not considered a primary source compared to whole grains like rice. The thiamine content in legumes is present but not in quantities significant enough to be considered the best option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).

 

Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.

questions.text: A woman purchased a food item from a shopkeeper who was subsequently arrested for food adulteration. Meanwhile, the woman develops visual disturbances and cardiac failure. The underlying toxin is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sanguinarine

 

The question describes a case of food adulteration that led to symptoms such as visual disturbances (Glaucoma) and cardiac failure. These symptoms are characteristic of a condition known as epidemic dropsy, which is caused by the consumption of adulterated mustard oil. The toxic adulterant in this case is Argemone mexicana oil, which contains the toxin sanguinarine. Sanguinarine inhibits the oxidation of pyruvic acid in the blood, leading to the symptoms observed in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BOAA: This is a toxin found in Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal) and can lead to neurolathyrism, a condition characterized by neuromuscular symptoms, not by visual disturbances or cardiac failure.

 

Option C. Ergot toxin: This toxin is associated with ergotism, which causes symptoms like hallucinations, gangrene, and convulsions.

 

Option D. Aflatoxin: Aflatoxin is a mycotoxin produced by Aspergillus species, often found in improperly stored food items like grains and nuts. It is a potent carcinogen but does not cause the acute symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration diseases:
