questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with painful genital ulcers along with painful inguinal buboes. He had a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

The patient's symptoms of painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) are characteristic of Chancroid. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and typically presents with painful ulcers on the genitals and tender, often pus-filled lymph nodes (buboes) in the groin.

 

When differentiating between sexually transmitted infections that cause genital ulcers, it is important to note whether the ulcers are painful or painless:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum): Incorrect because the genital ulcers in LGV are typically painless and transient. Although buboes are seen in LGV, the painful ulcers in this case suggest another diagnosis.

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: Incorrect because, although Herpes genitalis presents with painful ulcers, it usually does not involve painful inguinal buboes. Additionally, a history of recurrence might be mentioned, which is absent here.

 

Option D. Chancre (Syphilis): Incorrect because the ulcer in syphilis (chancre) is typically painless, and the lymphadenopathy is also painless.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid should be suspected in a patient with painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), especially in the absence of a history of recurrence and when syphilis and LGV have been ruled out based on the clinical presentation.

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

 

FIBROUS DYSPLASIA

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly of bone formation.
  • The hallmark is replacement of normal bone and marrow by fibrous tissue and small woven spicules of bone.
  • Fibrous dysplasia can occur in the epiphysis, metaphysis, or diaphysis.
  • It may affect one bone (monostotic form) or several bones (polyostotic form).
  • The monostotic form is the most common and is usually diagnosed in patients between 20 and 30 years of age. It most commonly affects the femur.
  • The polyostotic form typically manifests in children <10 years of age and may progress with age. It most commonly affects the maxilla and other craniofacial bones.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome refers to polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cutaneous pigmentation (café au lait spots), and endocrine abnormalities (Precoceous puberty).
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” borders).
  • Fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur has shepherd crook deformity.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.

 

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity (looks like shepherds stick which is crooked in shape) bone is replaced by fibrous tissue in fibrous dysplasia.

  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim, called ‘Rind sign’.

     

 

A. Shepherd Crook deformity; B. Rind sign 

 

  • Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).
    • On biopsy, Chinese Letter Pattern is recognised.
    • Surgical treatment (Curettage + bone grafting) is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blade of grass deformity. The blade of grass sign, also called the candle flame sign, refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen during the lytic phase of Paget disease of bone. The lytic, or incipient active, phase of the disease is characterized by intense osteoclastic activity that is exhibited on radiographs as osteolysis. In the long bones, osteolysis is manifested as a characteristic metaphyseal to diaphyseal wedge-shaped area of radiolucency that assumes the configuration of a flame or blade of grass. This advancing wedge of osteolysis, which begins in the subchondral bone of the epiphysis and extends peripherally into the metaphysis and diaphysis, spreads about 1 cm per year and shows no marginal sclerosis. A potential pitfall is misdiagnosing the track sign of the femur as the blade of grass sign.

 

 

Option C. Chicken wire appearance. Histopathologically, cellular areas in chondroblastoma are composed of “chondroblasts” with an oval to round nucleus and with well-defined eosinophilic cytoplasm. A fine network of pericellular calcification called “chicken wire calcification” are seen in the cytoplasm or stroma some cases.

 

 

Option D. Corduroy appearance. Hemangioma is a common benign bone lesion. It is estimated that 10% of the population has asymptomatic hemangioma of the vertebral bodies. Hemangiomas also are common in the skull. They usually are discovered as incidental findings. The radiographic appearance in the spine usually is characteristic, with thickened, vertically oriented trabeculae giving the classic “jailhouse” (Corduroy) appearance. In cross-section, these thickened trabeculae have a “polka dot” pattern on CT scan.

 

Treatment usually is not necessary.

 

 

Polka dot appearance on CT scan

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the OPD with a history of lower back pain and painful urination. On workup, it reveals normocytic normochromic anemia with hypercalcemia. Serum protein electrophoresis was done that shows M Spike in gamma region. Which of the following should be used to confirm the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bence Jones proteins in urine

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest that the patient may be suffering from multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a type of blood cancer that arises from plasma cells in the bone marrow. The characteristic features of multiple myeloma include:

 

  1. Lower back pain: Often related to lytic bone lesions caused by the disease.
  2. Normocytic normochromic anemia: A common finding due to the infiltration of bone marrow by malignant plasma cells.
  3. Hypercalcemia: Occurs due to increased bone resorption from lytic bone lesions.
  4. M Spike on serum protein electrophoresis: Represents a monoclonal protein or paraprotein, a hallmark of multiple myeloma.

 

To confirm the diagnosis, the detection of Bence Jones proteins in the urine is crucial. Bence Jones proteins are free light chains of immunoglobulins that are produced in excess by malignant plasma cells and can be detected in the urine of multiple myeloma patients. The presence of these proteins supports the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

 

Definitive diagnosis: Bone marrow biopsy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver function test: While it can be altered in various conditions, it is not specific or useful for diagnosing multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. UACR (urine albumin-creatinine ratio) test: This test is typically used to assess kidney function (stage & progression of disease), particularly in conditions like chronic kidney disease, and does not specifically confirm multiple myeloma.

 

Option D. Heat and acetic acid test: This is a basic test for proteinuria but does not specifically detect Bence Jones proteins or confirm multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detection of Bence Jones proteins in the urine is a key diagnostic test for confirming multiple myeloma, especially when the clinical presentation includes back pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and an M spike on serum protein electrophoresis.

questions.text: A patient experienced difficulty switching from one movement to another, along with uncontrollable hand movements. Identify the abnormality: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysdiadochokinesia

 

Explanation: 

 

Dysdiadochokinesia refers to the inability to perform rapid alternating movements smoothly and refers to cerebellar dysfunction. From the clinical presentation described - difficulty switching movements and uncontrollable hand movements - this is a classic case of dysdiadochokinesia. 

 

  • Di: two
  • Docho: alternate
  • Kinesis: movement 

 

This is one of the key signs of cerebellar disease, specifically affecting the coordination of voluntary movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intentional tremor: This occurs when a patient is performing a purposeful action and gets worse as they approach the target. 

 

Option C. Metamorphosis: This is seen in lesions of the amygdala or temporal lobe and refers to an uncontrollable urge to respond to every stimulus. It's not related to movement disorders.

 

Option D. Resting tremor: This is primarily seen in Parkinson's disease and occurs when the affected body part is at rest. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dysdiadochokinesia is a cerebellar sign characterized by inability to perform rapid alternating movements smoothly.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in Opioid Substitution Therapy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Buprenorphine


Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST) is a treatment given during the maintenance phase of opioid dependence. The goal is to reduce the harm associated with opioid use, such as the risks of HIV, Hepatitis, and illegal activities related to drug procurement. In OST, opioids like buprenorphine or methadone are used to replace more harmful opioids like heroin or morphine. These substitutions help control withdrawal symptoms and prevent relapse while allowing the patient to live a more stable life. Buprenorphine, being a partial opioid agonist, is preferred because it reduces cravings and withdrawal symptoms without the euphoric effects associated with other opioids, making it an effective substitute in OST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonidine: Clonidine is not used in OST because it is not an opioid. It may be used to manage withdrawal symptoms during detoxification but does not replace opioids during the maintenance phase.

 

Option B. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist, meaning it blocks the effects of opioids rather than substituting them. It can be used in the maintenance phase of opioid dependence but is not part of OST because it does not substitute one opioid for another.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used primarily to reverse opioid overdose. It is not used in OST because it does not have the substitutive effects needed for maintenance therapy in opioid dependence.

 

Educational Objective:


Opioid Substitution Therapy involves replacing a harmful opioid with a safer opioid like oral buprenorphine or methadone during the maintenance phase of treatment.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers
Alpha methyl dopa

questions.text: A 35-year woman is a chronic hypertensive. She visits the clinic for preconception counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensives need to be stopped prior to conception? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE inhibitors

 

Explanation:

 

ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:

 

  • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications.
  • They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death.
  • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons.
  • It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: These are generally considered safe during pregnancy and do not need to be discontinued.

 

Option B. Alpha methyl dopa: This is a safe and commonly used antihypertensive during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Labetalol: Labetalol is another safe option during pregnancy and is frequently used for managing hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers are contraindicated during pregnancy and should be discontinued prior to conception.

 

Ref: Page no 401, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

 

A ranula is a type of mucocele found on the floor of the mouth, associated with the sublingual gland. During the surgical excision of a ranula along with the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is at risk of being injured. The lingual nerve runs close to the sublingual gland and is responsible for sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Due to its proximity, it is the structure most likely to be damaged during such surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mylohyoid muscle: The mylohyoid muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is situated below the sublingual gland. It is less likely to be injured during the excision of a ranula as the procedure primarily involves the tissues above this muscle.

 

Option C. Submental artery: The submental artery supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the mylohyoid muscle. While it is in the general area, it is not as closely associated with the sublingual gland as the lingual nerve is, making it less likely to be injured during this specific procedure.

 

Option D. Sublingual artery: The sublingual artery supplies blood to the sublingual gland and the surrounding tissues. Although it is close to the surgical site, the risk of injury to the lingual nerve is higher due to its course and proximity to the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.
